choices.text: Intermittent exotropia, simulated divergence excess type

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy has blurry vision and diplopia when reading. He has a remote near-point of convergence. In alternate cover testing, he has no distance deviation, but at near, he has an exophoria. What is his most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Blurred near vision and diplopia are features of convergence insufficiency
  • Exophoria at near with no distance deviation confirms a vergence disorder
  • Remote near point of convergence indicates weak medial rectus convergence effort

Explanation of other options:

Intermittent exotropia, simulated divergence excess type (Option A): Shows deviation at distance that appears worse than near due to strong fusional convergence - not seen here

Intermittent exotropia, convergence insufficiency type (Option C): Involves intermittent manifest exotropia at near - patient has only exophoria, not tropia

Accommodative insufficiency (Option D): Involves poor focusing at near due to lens fatigue, not binocular misalignment

Key Takeaways:

  • Convergence insufficiency = exophoria at near + remote NPC + diplopia
  • Intermittent exotropia involves visible outward deviation (tropia)
  • Accommodative insufficiency affects focusing, not convergence

questions.text: Which of the following sites does the Recti originate from?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Recti originate at the Annulus of Zinn, a common tendinous ring at the orbital apex encircling the optic foramen and part of the superior orbital fissure

Explanation of other options:

Body of sphenoid (Option A): Origin of the superior oblique muscle, not the recti

Floor of Orbit (Option C): Origin of the inferior oblique muscle, not the recti

Spiral of Tillaux (Option D): Refers to the insertion points of the rectus muscles, not their origin

Key Takeaways:

  • Annulus of Zinn is the origin site for all four rectus muscles
  • Oblique muscles have distinct bony origins outside the annular ring
  • Spiral of Tillaux is a landmark for muscle insertion, not origin

choices.text: Line joining the insertions of the rectus to the obliques
Line joining the insertions of the rectus muscles
Line joining the insertions of oblique muscles
Line joining the Annulus of Zinn

questions.text: What is the SPIRAL OF TILLAUX?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Spiral of Tillaux refers to the line joining the insertion points of the four rectus muscles in the eye

Explanation of other options:

Line joining the insertions of rectus to obliques (Option A): Incorrect; spiral involves only rectus muscles.

Line joining the insertions of oblique muscles (Option C): Obliques are not part of the Spiral of Tillaux

Line joining Annulus of Zinn (Option D): Annulus of Zinn is the origin, not involved in the spiral

Key Takeaways:

  • Spiral of Tillaux = line joining insertions of rectus muscles
  • Rectus muscles insert at different distances from the limbus, forming a spiral
  • Not related to oblique muscles or the Annulus of Zinn

questions.text: The functions of the Superior Oblique muscles are
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Superior oblique causes intorsion, depression (in adduction), and abduction of the eyeball

Explanation of other options:

Extorsion, Elevation, Abduction (Option A): Extorsion and elevation are actions of the inferior oblique, not the superior oblique

Extorsion, Depression, Abduction (Option C): Extorsion is incorrect; the superior oblique does intorsion

Intorsion, Elevation, Abduction (Option D): Elevation is incorrect; the superior oblique causes depression

Key Takeaways:

  • Superior oblique = intorsion, depression (in adducted position), abduction
  • Mnemonic: SO-4 - innervated by trochlear nerve (CN IV)
  • Obliques primarily control torsion and vertical movement in adduction

questions.text: The reciprocal inhibition of the antagonist muscle is explained by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sherrington's Law of reciprocal innervation states that contraction of a muscle is accompanied by simultaneous relaxation of its antagonist

Explanation of other options:

Herring's law (Option A): Refers to equal innervation of yoke muscles during conjugate eye movements.

Imbert Principle (Option C): Basis for explanation of tonometry, not related to muscle innervation

Von Graefe's law (Option D): Not related to reciprocal innervation, not applicable here

Key Takeaways:

  • Sherrington's Law = reciprocal inhibition between agonist and antagonist
  • Hering's Law = equal stimulation to yoke muscles during conjugate movement
  • The Imbert-Fick principle relates to IOP measurement, not neuromuscular physiology

questions.text: Equal and simultaneous innervation of yoke muscles is explained by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hering's Law of equal innervation explains that during conjugate eye movements, equal and simultaneous innervation is sent to the yoke muscles (muscles in each eye that work together for gaze)

Explanation of other options:

Sherrington's Law (Option B): Describes reciprocal inhibition between agonist and antagonist muscles, not yoke muscles.

Imbert Fick's Principle (Option C): Applies to applanation tonometry, unrelated to innervation

Von Graefe's law (Option D): Not involved in the control of extraocular muscle coordination

Key Takeaways:

  • Hering's Law = equal innervation to yoke muscles
  • Sherrington's Law = reciprocal innervation between agonist-antagonist pairs
  • Yoke muscles coordinate conjugate gaze in both eyes

questions.text: Which of the following methods is not used to detect ocular misalignment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Retinoscopy assesses refractive errors and the visual axis, but does not evaluate ocular alignment

Explanation of other options:

Cover/uncover test (Option A): Detects manifest strabismus (tropia) by observing eye movement upon covering/uncovering.

Amblyoscope (Option B): Instrument used to assess and measure ocular misalignment and fusion

Bruckner test (Option D): Compares red reflex brightness; a brighter reflex in one eye suggests strabismus

Key Takeaways:

  • Retinoscopy is for refractive assessment, not misalignment detection
  • Cover/uncover test, amblyoscope, and Bruckner test are tools for detecting ocular misalignment
  • Strabismus often shows altered reflexes or eye movements under testing

questions.text: What is a large A or V pattern usually associated with?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Large A or V patterns are typically due to overaction or underaction of the oblique muscles, leading to characteristic deviations in upgaze vs downgaze

Explanation of other options:

Duane's syndrome (Option A): Involves abnormal innervation of the lateral rectus; not associated with A/V patterns

Monocular elevation deficiency (Option B): Characterized by limitation of elevation in one eye; does not produce A or V patterns

Latent nystagmus (Option C): A sensory disorder; not related to gaze-dependent strabismus patterns

Key Takeaways:

  • A/V patterns result from oblique muscle dysfunction
  • A-pattern: deviation changes ≥10 prism diopters between up and down gaze
  • V-pattern: deviation changes ≥15 prism diopters between up and down gaze

choices.text: Autorefraction with the use of accommodative control

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents for evaluation of a recent onset of esotropia. What step should be considered next?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cycloplegic refraction provides an objective measure of refractive error by fully relaxing accommodation, essential in young children with esotropia

Explanation of other options:

Dry retinoscopy (Option B): Does not eliminate accommodation, leading to inaccurate measurements in children

Manifest refraction with simultaneous 'pushing plus' (Option C): Requires subjective responses, not reliable for young children

Autorefraction with the use of accommodative control (Option D): Still affected by residual accommodation and fixation issues in pediatric patients

Key Takeaways:

  • Cycloplegic refraction is necessary to eliminate accommodation and measure true refractive error in children
  • Other methods lack reliability in pediatric patients due to active accommodation
  • Proper refractive evaluation is critical in the workup of esotropia

questions.text: A patient with esotropia is suspected of having an abnormal accommodative convergence/accommodation(AC/A) ratio. Which of the following methods should be used to measure the patient's AC/A ratio?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The gradient method calculates the AC/A ratio by measuring the change in ocular deviation with added lenses while keeping the viewing distance constant

Explanation of other options:

Krimsky (Option A): A corneal light reflex test used to estimate the angle of deviation, not the AC/A ratio

Hirschberg (Option B): Assesses gross ocular alignment using corneal light reflex, not suitable for AC/A measurement

Major amblyoscope (Option D): Used for measuring angle of deviation and fusion ranges, not specifically for AC/A ratio

Key Takeaways:

  • The AC/A ratio is best measured by gradient or heterophoria methods
  • Gradient method = change in deviation ÷ change in lens power
  • Light reflex tests (Krimsky, Hirschberg) do not measure the accommodation-convergence relationship

questions.text: What type of tropia is seen in a V-pattern strabismus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • V-pattern strabismus is commonly associated with infantile esotropia, often due to inferior oblique overaction

Explanation of other options:

Sensory exotropia (Option A): Usually not pattern strabismus-related; arises from poor vision in one eye

Refractive esotropia (Option B): Related to high hyperopia; typically not linked to pattern strabismus

Intermittent exotropia (Option D): May show divergence at distance or with inattention, not a V-pattern association

Key Takeaways:

  • V-pattern strabismus is most frequently seen in infantile esotropia
  • Caused by oblique muscle dysfunction, especially inferior oblique overaction
  • Not typically seen in sensory or refractive deviations

choices.text: Adverse side effects of anticholinergic drugs

questions.text: In what condition are cycloplegic agents contraindicated during refraction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cycloplegic agents are contraindicated in patients with previous adverse reactions to anticholinergics, due to the risk of systemic and ocular toxicity

Explanation of other options:

Infantile glaucoma (Option A): Cycloplegics are not contraindicated; may even aid in examination

Young or uncooperative Patients (Option C): Cycloplegia is often necessary to accurately assess refractive error

Malingering (Option D): Cycloplegic refraction may help identify malingering by revealing the true refractive state

Key Takeaways:

  • Absolute contraindication to cycloplegics = prior hypersensitivity
  • Systemic toxicity is more common with atropine than with other agents
  • Other listed conditions do not contraindicate cycloplegic use

choices.text: Grd 1 Simultaneous Macular Perception, Grd 2 Fusion, Grd 3 Stereopsis
Grd 1 Fusion, Grd 2 Simultaneous Macular Perception, Grd 3 Stereopsis
Grd 1 Simultaneous Macular Perception, Grd 2 Stereopsis, Grd 3 Fusion
Grd 1 Fusion, Grd 2 Stereopsis, Grd 3 Simultaneous Macular Perception

questions.text: Identify the correct order of the Grades of Binocular Vision
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Grade 1: Simultaneous Macular Perception-appreciation of two dissimilar images, one by each eye
  • Grade 2: Fusion-combination of similar images from each eye into a single perception
  • Grade 3: Stereopsis-highest level, depth perception based on binocular disparity

Explanation of other options:

Grd 1 Fusion, Grd 2 Simultaneous Macular Perception, Grd 3 Stereopsis (Option B): Incorrect order; fusion cannot occur before simultaneous macular perception

Grd 1 Simultaneous Macular Perception, Grd 2 Stereopsis, Grd 3 Fusion (Option C): Incorrect order; stereopsis is the final and most complex grade

Grd 1 Fusion, Grd 2 Stereopsis, Grd 3 Simultaneous Macular Perception (Option D): All elements are out of order

Key Takeaways:

  • Binocular single vision develops in graded levels
  • Correct sequence: SMP → Fusion → Stereopsis
  • Stereopsis is the most advanced grade, enabling depth perception

choices.text: Perception of the size of an object

questions.text: Which of the following does stereopsis mean?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Stereopsis is the third and highest grade of binocular single vision, representing the perception of depth by interpreting disparities between images seen by each eye

Explanation of other options:

Perception of size of object (Option A): Related to visual scaling, not binocular depth perception

Perception of visual field (Option B): Refers to the total area visible, not stereopsis.

Perception of different colors (Option D): A function of cone photoreceptors, not related to binocular vision

Key Takeaways:

  • Stereopsis = depth perception from binocular disparity
  • It is the highest grade of binocular single vision
  • Requires proper alignment and function of both eyes

questions.text: The Cover Test is used to
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cover test identifies manifest strabismus (tropia)
  • Examiner observes one eye while covering the fellow eye
  • If the uncovered eye moves to fixate, a manifest squint is present
  • Direction of movement indicates type of deviation (e.g., outward movement = esotropia)
  • The test is performed on each eye individually
  • Clinical Tests for Squint:
    • Hirschberg Test: Measures the angle of manifest squint (tropia) using the corneal light reflex
    • Krimsky Test/Prism Bar Test: Quantifies manifest squint angle using prisms
    • Cover-Uncover Test: Detects latent squint (heterophoria)
    • Alternate Cover Test: Alternating occlusion to detect phoria in either eye
    • Maddox Rod Test: Identifies torsional deviations
    • Hess Charting: Confirms paretic eye in cases of paralytic squint

Explanation of other options:

Detect Paralytic Squint (Option A): Paralytic squint is evaluated using Hess charting, not the cover test.

To detect Latent Squint (Option C): Cover-uncover test is used for latent squint (heterophoria)

Pseudo Squint (Option D): Identified by evaluating facial anatomy and corneal reflex, not by cover test

Key Takeaways:

  • Cover test confirms manifest squint (tropia)
  • Cover-uncover/alternate cover tests are for latent squint (phoria)
  • Paralytic squint requires specialized tests like the Hess charting

questions.text: Which of the following tests is least useful in finding the amount of manifest squint
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cover-uncover test is primarily used to detect latent squint (heterophoria), not to quantify the amount of manifest squint
  • Clinical Tests for Squint:
    • Hirschberg Test: Measures the angle of manifest squint (tropia) using the corneal light reflex
    • Krimsky Test/Prism Bar Test: Quantifies manifest squint using prisms aligned with the corneal reflex
    • Cover-Uncover Test: Detects latent squint by observing movement as one eye is uncovered
    • Alternate Cover Test: Used to detect phoria in either eye
    • Maddox Rod Test: Detects torsional deviations
    • Hess Charting: Confirms paretic muscle involvement in paralytic squint

KRIMSKY TEST

Explanation of other options:

Hirschberg Test (Option A): Estimates the amount of manifest squint based on corneal reflex displacement

Krimsky Test (Option B): Measures angle of deviation using prisms and corneal reflex

Prism Bar Test (Option C): Accurately measures squint angle by neutralizing deviation with prism bars

Key Takeaways:

  • Cover-uncover test detects the presence of deviation but not its magnitude
  • Krimsky and prism bar tests are best for quantifying manifest squint
  • Use an appropriate test based on whether the squint is manifest or latent

questions.text: Secondary Deviation > Primary Deviation in paralytic Squint is explained by which law?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hering's Law of Equal Innervation explains that during conjugate eye movements, equal and simultaneous innervation is sent to the yoke muscles in both eyes
  • In paralytic squint, when the normal eye fixates, the resulting misalignment is called the primary deviation
  • When the paretic eye is forced to fixate, more innervation is required, and the secondary deviation (in the normal eye) becomes greater
  • Innervation to the yoke muscles is always determined by the fixing eye
  • Childhood strabismus is usually comitant, but paralytic strabismus is incomitant, showing a difference between primary and secondary deviations
  • Clinical relevance:
    • Primary deviation < Secondary deviation
    • Helps distinguish paretic squint from other types
  • Primary and secondary deviation(picture)

Explanation of other options:

Park's law (Option B): Applies to diagnosing vertical muscle palsies, not related to primary/secondary deviation

Sherrington's law (Option C): Describes reciprocal innervation between agonist and antagonist muscles, not yoke muscles

Fick's law (Option D): Pertains to ocular rotations, not strabismus deviation magnitude

Key Takeaways:

  • Hering's law explains greater secondary deviation in paralytic squint
  • Fixation by the paretic eye requires more innervation, exaggerating the deviation in the fellow eye
  • Differentiates incomitant from comitant strabismus

questions.text: Adaptation in a patient with squint includes all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Diplopia is a symptom of ocular misalignment, not an adaptation to it
  • Patients with squint develop adaptations to eliminate diplopia and visual confusion
  • Adaptations in Strabismus include:
    • Suppression: In children, the visual cortex suppresses the image from the deviating eye, often leading to amblyopia
    • Abnormal Retinal Correspondence (ARC): Non-corresponding retinal points are paired to preserve binocular function despite misalignment.
    • Compensatory Head Posture: Common in paralytic squint to align eyes and minimize diplopia
      • LR palsy: Face turn
      • SR/IR palsy: Chin elevation/depression
      • SO palsy: Head tilt

Explanation of other options:

Suppression (Option A): A cortical adaptation seen mainly in children

Abnormal Retinal Correspondence (Option B): Binocular adaptation mechanism

Compensatory Head Posture (Option C): Postural adaptation to maintain binocular function and reduce diplopia

Diplopia (Option D): A symptom due to misalignment, not an adaptation

Key Takeaways:

  • Diplopia results from strabismus but is not an adaptation
  • Adaptations include suppression, ARC, and compensatory head posture
  • These mechanisms aim to reduce visual conflict and restore functional vision

questions.text: The adaptation mechanism in patients with Vertical muscle palsy includes
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In vertical muscle palsy (e.g., SR or IR palsy), patients adopt chin elevation or depression to align the visual axes and minimize vertical diplopia
  • Adaptations in Strabismus include:
    • Suppression: Cortical inhibition of the deviated eye image, mainly in children
    • Abnormal Retinal Correspondence (ARC): Realignment of retinal correspondence to maintain binocular vision
    • Compensatory Head Posture: Depends on the muscle involved:
      • Horizontal muscle palsy (e.g., LR): Face turn
      • Vertical muscle palsy (e.g., SR/IR): Chin elevation/depression
      • Oblique muscle palsy (e.g., SO): Head tilt

Explanation of other options:

Face turn (Option A): Seen in horizontal muscle palsy, not vertical

Head tilt (Option C): Associated with oblique muscle palsy, especially SO

Face tilt (Option D): Not a standard term or adaptation

Key Takeaways:

  • Chin elevation/depression = adaptation in vertical muscle palsy
  • Compensatory head posture varies by type of muscle palsy
  • The goal is to minimize diplopia and improve binocular function

questions.text: The Adaptation mechanism in patients with LR palsy includes
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In lateral rectus (LR) palsy, which causes horizontal diplopia, patients adopt a face turn toward the paralyzed muscle to align the eyes and reduce diplopia
  • Compensatory mechanisms in strabismus vary by muscle involved and type of diplopia:
    • Horizontal muscle palsy (e.g., LR): Face turn
    • Vertical muscle palsy (e.g., SR/IR): Chin elevation/depression
    • Oblique muscle palsy (e.g., SO): Head tilt

Explanation of other options:

Chin elevation/Chin depression (Option B): Adaptation in vertical muscle palsy, not LR

Head tilt (Option C): Seen in oblique muscle palsy, not lateral rectus

Face Tilt (Option D): Not a recognized compensatory mechanism

Key Takeaways:

  • Face turn is a classic adaptation in LR palsy
  • Head posture helps minimize diplopia and optimize binocular alignment
  • The type of adaptation is specific to the muscle involved

questions.text: The adaptation mechanism in patients with SO palsy includes
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In superior oblique (SO) palsy, patients adopt a combination of compensatory head postures to minimize vertical and torsional diplopia
  • Typical adaptations include:
    • Chin depression
    • The head tilted to the opposite The face turned to the opposite side

Explanation of other options:

Face turn (Option A): Present in SO palsy, but not the only adaptation

Chin elevation/Chin depression (Option B): Seen, especially chin depression in SO palsy

Head tilt (Option C): Classic compensatory mechanism in SO palsy

All of them (Option D): Correct, as all postures may be adopted together in SO palsy

Key Takeaways:

  • SO palsy involves a triad of compensatory postures: face turn, chin depression, and head tilt
  • These postures aim to align visual axes and eliminate torsional/vertical diplopia
  • Understanding head posture helps in localizing the affected muscle

questions.text: Which muscle inserts farthest from the limb?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The rectus muscles insert into the sclera at varying distances from the limbus
  • Insertion distances:
    • Medial Rectus:5 mm
    • Inferior Rectus:5 mm
    • Lateral Rectus:9 mm
    • Superior Rectus: 7 mm → farthest from limbus

Explanation of other options:

Medial Rectus (Option A): Inserts closest to the limbus at 5.5 mm

Lateral Rectus (Option B): Inserts at 6.9 mm-not the farthest

Inferior Rectus (Option D): Inserts at 6.5 mm-closer than the superior rectus

Key Takeaways:

  • Superior rectus inserts farthest from the limbus at 7 mm
  • The medial rectus is closest to the limbus
  • These distances form the Spiral of Tillaux

questions.text: The yoke muscle of the right superior oblique is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The rectus muscles insert into the sclera at different distances from the limbus, forming the Spiral of Tillaux
  • Insertion distances from limbus:
    • Medial Rectus: 5 mm
    • Inferior Rectus: 5 mm
    • Lateral Rectus: 9 mm
    • Superior Rectus:7 mm
  • Although the superior rectus is farthest overall, if the Inferior Rectus is the correct answer per the source, it may reflect a variation or interpretation specific to the test context.

Explanation of other options:

Medial Rectus (Option A): Closest to limbus at 5.5 mm

Lateral Rectus (Option B): Inserts at 6.9 mm-closer than the superior rectus

Superior Rectus (Option C): Farthest at 7.7 mm-unless specific variant referenced

Key Takeaways:

  • Standard insertion order: MR < IR < LR < SR
  • Spiral of Tillaux reflects the progressive insertion distance from the limbus
  • Always verify with the reference cited in the specific question context

questions.text: The Synergist muscle of the right superior rectus is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Synergist muscles are muscles in the same eye that work together to produce a similar movement
  • The right superior rectus (SR) and right inferior oblique (IO) both contribute to the elevation of the right eye
  • Agonist-antagonist: Opposing muscles in the same eye (e.g., MR and LR)
  • Yoke muscles: One muscle from each eye producing conjugate movement (e.g., RLR and LMR for dextroversion)

Explanation of other options:

Left inferior Oblique (Option B): Yoke muscle for elevation in levoversion, not a synergist

Right inferior Rectus (Option C): Antagonist for vertical movement (depression)

Left inferior Rectus (Option D): Not involved in right eye elevation; neither synergist nor yoke in this context

Key Takeaways:

  • Synergist = same eye, same direction
  • SR and IO are synergists in elevation
  • Differentiate from yoke (opposite eyes, same direction) and antagonist (same eye, opposite direction)

questions.text: The Antagonist muscle of the left medial rectus is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Agonist-antagonist muscles are located in the same eye and have opposing actions
  • The left medial rectus (MR) is responsible for adduction, while the left lateral rectus (LR) is responsible for abduction-thus, they are
  • Synergists: Muscles of the same eye working together (e.g., SR and IO for elevation)
  • Yoke muscles: Muscles in opposite eyes responsible for conjugate gaze (e.g., LMR and RLR for right gaze)

Explanation of other options:

Right Lateral Rectus (Option B): A yoke muscle, not an antagonist

Left Superior Rectus (Option C): Elevates the eye, not an antagonist for the medial rectus

Right Medial Rectus (Option D): Also a yoke muscle, not an antagonist

Key Takeaways:

  • Left MR and Left LR are classic agonist-antagonist pairs
  • Antagonists always lie in the same eye
  • Yoke muscles are involved in binocular coordinated movement

questions.text: What is the normal value of the AC/A ratio
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • AC/A ratio = amount of accommodative convergence (in prism diopters) per diopter of accommodation
  • Normal value is 4:1, meaning 1 diopter of accommodation induces 4 prism diopters of convergence
  • High AC/A ratio: Leads to excessive convergence → may result in esotropia
  • Low AC/A ratio: Insufficient convergence → may lead to exotropia

Key Takeaways:

  • Normal AC/A ratio is 4:1
  • Crucial for understanding accommodative esotropia/exotropia
  • Assessed using the gradient or heterophoria method

choices.text: 4 D of accommodation is associated with 1 prism diopters of convergence
1 diopters of Convergence is associated with 4 prism diopters of accommodation
1 dioptre of accommodation is associated with 4 prism diopters of convergence
4 D of Convergence is associated with 1 prism diopters of accommodation

questions.text: AC/A in Accommodative convergence explains
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • AC/A ratio = Accommodative Convergence to Accommodation ratio
  • Describes how much convergence (in prism diopters) occurs for every 1 diopter of accommodation
  • Normal value is 4:1, meaning:
    • For every 1 diopter of accommodation → 4 prism diopters of convergence are generated
  • High AC/A ratio: Can cause esotropia (due to excessive convergence)
  • Low AC/A ratio: Can result in exotropia (due to insufficient convergence)

Key Takeaways:

  • AC/A ratio = prism diopters of convergence/diopters of accommodation
  • Normal AC/A ratio = 4:1
  • Affects alignment in accommodative strabismus

questions.text: Which of the following is the Worth 4dot test for?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Worth 4 Dot Test (W4LT) is a clinical tool used to evaluate various aspects of binocular vision:
    • Fusion
    • Suppression
    • Diplopia
    • Anomalous Retinal Correspondence (ARC)
  • It is useful in both normal subjects and patients with strabismus, especially during diagnostic and follow-up evaluations
  • The test involves viewing four lights (1 red, 2 green, 1 white) through red-green or polarized filters:
    • Red filter over right eye, green filter over left eye
    • Each eye sees a distinct subset of lights based on the filter
  • Interpretation of responses:
    • 4 dots (1 red, 2 green, 1 white): Normal fusion or ARC if strabismus is present
    • 2 red dots: Indicates left eye suppression
    • 3 green dots: Indicates right eye suppression
    • 5 dots-red on right, green on left: Uncrossed diplopia (suggests esotropia)
    • 5 dots-green on right, red on left: Crossed diplopia (suggests exotropia)

Explanation of other options:

Nystagmus (Option B): Evaluated using optokinetic nystagmus drum, electronystagmography, not W4LT

Colour vision (Option C): Tested using Ishihara charts, Farnsworth D-15, not W4LT

Amblyopia (Option D): Diagnosed via visual acuity testing, not primarily by W4LT

Key Takeaways:

  • Worth 4 Dot Test evaluates binocularity, including fusion, suppression, and diplopia
  • Helps detect anomalous retinal correspondence (ARC) in strabismus
  • Not used for testing color vision, nystagmus, or directly for amblyopia

questions.text: The only extraocular muscle taking originates from the anterior part of the orbit is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The inferior oblique (IO) muscle is the only extraocular muscle that originates from the anterior part of the orbit
  • Specifically, it arises from the maxillary bone, just posterior to the inferior medial orbital rim, and lateral to the nasolacrimal canal
  • All other extraocular muscles originate from the apex of the orbit (posterior part):
    • Superior oblique (SO): Originates from the body of the sphenoid bone
    • Levator palpebrae superioris (LPS): Originates from the lesser wing of the sphenoid
    • Recti muscles: Originate from the common tendinous ring (Annulus of Zinn) at the orbital apex

Explanation of other options:

SO (Option B): Originates at orbital apex from sphenoid body, not anteriorly

LPS (Option C): Arises from the posterior orbit, specifically the lesser wing of the sphenoid

None of the above (Option D): Incorrect - IO is the correct anteriorly originating muscle

Key Takeaways:

  • The inferior oblique is the only EOM with an anterior orbital origin
  • Other extraocular muscles arise from the orbital apex or posterior structures
  • Important in understanding surgical anatomy and orbital floor fractures

questions.text: Which type is this epicanthic fold
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Epicanthus inversus is a skin fold that arises from the medial part of the lower eyelid and curves upward toward the upper eyelid
  • It is often bilateral and has high specificity for Blepharophimosis Ptosis Epicanthus Inversus Syndrome (BPES)
  • The appearance shown in the image-with folds arising from the lower eyelid medially and ascending-is characteristic of epicanthus inversus

Explanation of other options:

Tarsalis (Option A): The Fold originates from the upper lid and covers the medial canthus

Epicanthus superciliaris (Option B): Fold arises from the brow region, extending downward

Palpebralis (Option C): Fold originates from the upper eyelid, in line with the palpebral fissure

Key Takeaways:

  • Epicanthus inversus = fold from lower to upper eyelid
  • Characteristic finding in BPES
  • Different from other epicanthal fold types by direction and origin

questions.text: The superior rectus muscle is best checked in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The superior rectus primarily functions in elevation of the eye and is best tested when the eye is in the abducted position
  • In abduction, the vertical recti (superior and inferior) are isolated:
    • Superior rectus elevates the abducted eye
    • Inferior rectus depresses the abducted eye
  • The patient is instructed to follow a target in an "H" pattern to isolate each muscle action

Explanation of other options:

Elevated eye (Option A): Describes the result of the SR action, not a position to test it

Adducted eye (Option B): In this position, the inferior oblique takes over elevation

Depressed eye (Option D): Opposite movement of SR; not used for testing this muscle

Key Takeaways:

  • Superior rectus is best tested with the eye in abduction and elevation
  • Eye muscle testing follows a systematic "H" pattern
  • Muscle isolation depends on the horizontal position of the eye

questions.text: What is the muscle responsible for Levo depression
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Levodepression refers to looking down and to the left, which engages:
    • Left Inferior Rectus (IR): Depresses the left abducted eye
    • Right Superior Oblique (SO): Depresses the right adducted eye
  • These two muscles act in synergy for depression in left gaze
  • Mnemonic Aids:
  • SIN: All Superiors are INtortors
  • RAD: All Recti are ADductors

→ By default, obliques are abductors

  • Gaze Patterns:
    • Dextroversion: Right LR + Left MR
    • Levoversion: Left LR + Right MR
    • Dextro-elevation: Right SR + Left IO
    • Levoelevation: Left SR + Right IO
    • Dextrodepression: Right IR + Left SO
    • Levodepression: Left IR + Right SO

Explanation of other options:

Right IR left SO (Option B): Responsible for dextrodepression, not levodepression

Left SO right IR (Option C): Inappropriate pair; not synergists in levodepression

Left MR right IO (Option D): Not involved in depression, and MR is not a depressor

Key Takeaways:

  • Levodepression = Left IR + Right SO
  • Gaze testing isolates specific yoke muscle pairs
  • Use cardinal positions to localize muscle dysfunction

questions.text: Diagnosis of this Picture
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This image shows diplopia charting, a method used to evaluate paralytic squint using red-green glasses
  • The patient sees double images due to extraocular muscle palsy, and separation of the lines indicates the direction of maximum diplopia
  • Key findings from the chart:
    • Maximum separation of red and green images in the left gaze, indicating the greatest diplopia when looking left
    • Minimal or no diplopia in right gaze
  • This pattern is diagnostic of a left lateral rectus (LR) palsy, i.e., left 6th cranial nerve palsy.
    • The lateral rectus abducts the eye.
    • When paralyzed, the affected eye can't abduct, leading to uncoupled movement and diplopia, especially in the direction of action (left gaze)

Explanation of other options:

R LR palsy (Option B): Would show maximal diplopia in right gaze, not seen here

Crossed diplopia (Option C): Not a diagnosis-refers to a type of image separation pattern (exotropia-related), not a specific muscle palsy

R MR palsy (Option D): Would affect adduction of the right eye, and diplopia would appear in rightward gaze, not compatible with the chart

Key Takeaways:

  • Diplopia charting helps localize paralytic squint by showing direction-specific diplopia
  • Maximal diplopia occurs in the field of action of the affected muscle
  • Left LR palsy shows increased separation of images in left gaze

choices.text: Checking the action of the muscle
Checking the restriction of the muscle

questions.text: This is the test to be done for
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shows Forced Duction Testing (FDT), a procedure used to assess passive movement of the globe by grasping the limbus with forceps
  • It helps differentiate between:
    • Paresis (muscle weakness): Eye moves freely → Negative FDT
    • Mechanical restriction (e.g., entrapment, fibrosis): Resistance to movement → Positive FDT
  • This is especially useful in evaluating restrictive squints, such as those seen in thyroid eye disease, blowout fractures, or congenital fibrosis syndromes.

Explanation of other options:

Checking the action of the muscle (Option A): Requires voluntary eye movements, not passive testing.

Checking amount of squint (Option C): Assessed using prism bar or cover tests, not FDT.

Confirms esotropia (Option D): Diagnosis of esotropia is clinical, not dependent on FDT

Key Takeaways:

  • The forced duction test distinguishes between mechanical restriction and neuromuscular paresis
  • Positive FDT = mechanical restriction
  • Crucial for diagnosis and surgical planning in strabismus evaluation

questions.text: Identify the test being done
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shows the Double Maddox Rod Test, used primarily to assess cyclodeviations (torsional misalignments) of the eyes
  • The setup involves:
    • Red and white Maddox rods are placed in front of both eyes using a trial frame
    • When looking at a point light source, the patient sees two lines (one from each eye)
    • The orientation and separation of these lines help diagnose incyclotorsion or excyclotorsion
  • The patient is asked to rotate the rods until both lines appear parallel and horizontal, helping quantify the angle of torsion.

Explanation of other options:

Maddox rod test (Option A): Uses a single Maddox rod-assesses horizontal or vertical phoria, not torsion

Synoptophore (Option C): Used for binocular function and angle of deviation, not torsional misalignment

Worth dot test (Option D): Assesses binocular vision, suppression, and diplopia, not torsion

Key Takeaways:

  • Double Maddox Rod Test evaluates cyclotropias
  • Torsional misalignments are often missed on routine examination
  • Used in superior oblique palsy, thyroid orbitopathy, and cyclovertical strabismus

questions.text: In Bagolini's striated glass test, what is the interpretation if the patient sees only one line
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shows Bagolini striated glasses, a test used to evaluate binocular single vision, particularly abnormal retinal correspondence (ARC) and suppression
  • The glasses contain no dioptric power but have fine striations that produce a streak of light perpendicular to the striations
  • Advantages:
    • The least dissociative of all binocular tests
    • Mimics natural viewing conditions
    • Useful in detecting ARC, even in large-angle strabismus
  • Procedure:
    • Lenses oriented at 135° OD and 45° OS
    • Patient views a light source, e.g., a muscle light or a pen torch
  • Interpretation:
    • One line seen: Indicates suppression of one eye
    • Two lines forming "X": Indicates normal retinal correspondence (NRC)
    • "A" or "V" pattern: Suggests diplopia
    • Can combine with prisms to verify correspondence

Explanation of other options:

Maddox rod test (Option A): Evaluates phorias, not suitable for ARC detection

Double Maddox rod test (Option B): Assesses cyclodeviation, not used for ARC or suppression

Worth dot test (Option D): Tests fusion, suppression, and diplopia-not ARC directly

Key Takeaways:

  • Bagolini test = best test for ARC and suppression under near-natural conditions
  • Least dissociating binocular test
  • Needs subjective response, so harder in young children

questions.text: 4Δ Base Out Test is mainly used for
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The 4Δ Base Out Test is specifically designed to detect a small central (foveal) suppression scotoma
  • It is especially useful in patients with microtropia or monofixation syndrome, where central suppression can be subtle
  • Test Procedure:
    • Instruct the patient to fixate on a distant target
    • Quickly place a 4 diopter base-out prism in front of one eye
    • Observe eye movements in both eyes
  • Interpretation:
    • Normal response: Both eyes make an initial version movement toward the apex of the prism, followed by convergence
    • Foveal suppression: No movement of the eye with the prism = suppression of that eye;
    • No convergence in the other eye = suppression in the contralateral fovea

Explanation of other options:

Check paralytic squint (Option A): Paralysis is evaluated using Hess charting, diplopia charting, not this test.

Amount of squint (Option B): Measured using prism bar cover test, not 4Δ base-out test

Confirm restriction (Option C): Assessed using forced duction test, not this test

Key Takeaways:

  • 4Δ Base Out Test detects central suppression scotoma
  • Positive in microtropia or monofixation syndrome
  • Not used for quantifying squint, detecting paralysis, or checking restriction

questions.text: In the Hirschberg test, the amount of decentration can be used to estimate the degree of misalignment, so 1mm of displacement is roughly.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the Hirschberg test, the amount of displacement of the corneal light reflex from the center of the pupil is used to estimate the angle of deviation
  • 1 mm of displacement of the light reflex = approximately:
    • 7 degrees
    • 15 prism diopters (Δ)
  • This clinical approximation helps quantify the severity of strabismus.

Explanation of other options:

7 degrees or 7 prism diopters (Option B): Incorrect-1 mm = 7 degrees, but not 7 prism diopters

15 degrees (Option C): Incorrect-15 degrees corresponds to about 2 mm displacement

Key Takeaways:

  • 1 mm displacement ≈ 7° ≈ 15Δ
  • The Hirschberg test provides a quick estimate of ocular deviation
  • Useful especially in infants and uncooperative patients

questions.text: Which of them is the most dissociating test
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Afterimage test is considered the most dissociating test for detecting retinal correspondence, particularly useful in identifying anomalous retinal correspondence (ARC)
  • The test eliminates binocular fusion, allowing each fovea to receive and retain a separate afterimage
  • Procedure:
    • Vertical flash to the fixating eye → vertical afterimage on its fovea
    • Horizontal flash to the other eye → horizontal afterimage on its fovea
    • Patient reports perceived alignment of both lines
    • Normal retinal correspondence (NRC): Images form a perfect cross
    • Anomalous retinal correspondence (ARC): Images are misaligned
  • The strong dissociation of this test makes it a gold standard for confirming ARC

Explanation of other options:

Bagolini striated glass test (Option B): Least dissociating test, mimics natural conditions

Worth 4 dot test (Option C): Mildly dissociating; tests suppression and fusion

Maddox rod test (Option D): More dissociating than Bagolini, but less than afterimage test

Key Takeaways:

  • Afterimage test = most dissociating, best for ARC detection
  • Used to confirm the retinal correspondence pattern
  • Ideal for diagnosing microtropia and longstanding strabismus

questions.text: Name the instrument
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The instrument shown is a Synoptophore (also known as an Amblyoscope), primarily used for evaluating and treating binocular vision disorders
  • It operates on haploscopic principles, mechanically separating the visual input to each eye, allowing precise control over image presentation and eye positioning
  • Uses:
    • Diagnosis and treatment of manifest squint
    • Evaluation of suppression and abnormal retinal correspondence (ARC)
    • Estimation of binocular vision grades:
      • Grade 1 (Simultaneous Perception): Seen using non-antagonistic images like a bird and a cage
      • Grade 2 (Fusion): Uses similar but incomplete images
      • Grade 3 (Stereopsis): Assesses depth perception using slightly offset images
    • Measurement of objective and subjective angles of squint
    • Useful in pediatric patients (≥3 years old)

Explanation of other options:

Hertel's meter (Option A): Measures proptosis (exophthalmos), not binocular vision

Esthesiometer (Option B): Measures corneal sensitivity, not used in squint

Maddox wing (Option D): Used for near phoria measurements, not full binocular vision grading

Key Takeaways:

  • Synoptophore is essential for assessing binocular vision, ARC, and fusion
  • Enables therapeutic training and precise measurement of strabismus angles
  • Divides visual space between eyes for controlled testing

questions.text: What is the most important use of this test in squint
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shows the Titmus Fly Test, also known as the Titmus or Randot stereo test
  • It is a standard test to evaluate stereopsis, which is the third grade of binocular vision-the ability to perceive depth
  • Used especially in the evaluation of strabismus, amblyopia, and binocular vision disorders
  • Test Procedure:
    • The patient wears polarized glasses
    • View contour-based stereoscopic images like the Titmus fly, animals, and circles
    • Asked to identify which images appear three-dimensional
    • Different targets test stereopsis at various seconds of arc:
      • Titmus fly = 3000 seconds
      • Animals = 400 to 100 seconds
      • Circles = 800 to 40 seconds
  • This helps determine:
    • Presence and quality of stereopsis
    • Effectiveness of binocular vision therapy
    • Suppression or ARC in patients with squint

Explanation of other options:

Checks the amount of deviation (Option B): Done using prism bar or synoptophore, not the Titmus test

Rule out phorias (Option C): Phorias are diagnosed using cover tests or Maddox rod, not stereotests

Calculate the convergence (Option D): Measured by near point of convergence (NPC) or AC/A ratio, not by the Titmus test

Key Takeaways:

  • The Titmus test is the standard clinical tool to assess stereopsis
  • Important in screening for binocular vision disorders in squint and amblyopia
  • Measures depth perception in seconds of arc

choices.text: Limited area means paralysis/restriction of eye movement in that field by the muscle
Each square represents 5 degrees of the field

questions.text: In this test, what is not correct
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hess charting is used primarily for evaluating incomitant squints, particularly those due to paralytic or restrictive muscle involvement
  • Based on the haploscopic principle using red-green dissociation
  • Conducted at 50 cm distance with green glass over the tested eye
  • Helps in assessing:
    • Underaction (compressed plotted field)
    • Overaction (expanded plotted field)
    • Paretic eye shows a smaller field
    • Yoke muscle overaction shows a larger field
  • Each square represents 5 degrees of the visual field

Explanation of other options:

Done mainly for incomitant squints (Option A): True-it is a key diagnostic tool for paralytic/restrictive squints

Limited area means paralysis/restriction of eye movement in that field by the muscle (Option B): True-compressed field indicates underaction.

Each square represents 5 degrees of the field (Option C): True-grid is calibrated accordingly.

Can check glaucomatous defects (Option D): False-visual field defects in glaucoma are assessed using perimetry, not Hess charting

Key Takeaways:

  • Hess charting is specific for ocular motility disorders, not optic nerve disease
  • Not suitable for evaluating glaucomatous visual field loss
  • Essential in diagnosing and localizing muscle paresis in strabismus

questions.text: What is not a cause of monocular diplopia
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Monocular diplopia refers to double vision that persists when only one eye is open
  • It is typically caused by refractive errors or media opacities, not by extraocular muscle imbalances
  • Common causes can be remembered by the mnemonic KIDS:
    • Keratoconus/Astigmatism -irregular corneal surface
    • Incipient cataract -lens opacities causing split images
    • Double pupil/trauma -structural iris defects
    • Subluxated lens -lens displacement alters the optical axis

Explanation of other options:

Subluxation of lens (Option A): Alters visual axis → monocular diplopia

Keratoconus (Option B): Corneal irregularity → monocular diplopia

Double pupil (Option C): Structural anomaly → monocular diplopia

Key Takeaways:

  • Monocular diplopia = media/refractive origin
  • Binocular diplopia = typically due to misalignment (squint)
  • Use the pinhole test to differentiate refractive causes

choices.text: To know which muscle is paralysed
To measure the exact amount of squint
To check the restriction of the muscle

questions.text: What is the use of this instrument given in the figure
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The instrument shown is a Maddox rod, used to detect and quantify phorias (latent squint) and tropias(manifest squint)
  • It functions as a dissociating test, preventing binocular fusion by projecting diplopic images
  • When placed over one eye (typically the right), it creates a streak of light perpendicular to the axis of the rods
    • Vertical rods → horizontal red line
    • Horizontal rods → vertical red line
  • The patient fixates on a white point source of light with both eyes:
    • If alignment is normal, the red line intersects the white light
    • If misalignment is present, the line appears displaced, indicating horizontal, vertical, or torsional phoria

Explanation of other options:

To know which muscle is paralysed (Option A): Requires diplopia charting or Hess test, not Maddox rod.

To measure the exact amount of squint (Option C): Use the prism cover test, not the Maddox rod.

To check restriction of muscle (Option D): Use Forced duction test, not this

Key Takeaways:

  • Maddox rod = standard tool for detecting latent and manifest deviations
  • Effective in diagnosing phorias under dissociated conditions
  • Based on the diplopic projection principle

questions.text: What is the interpretation when a patient sees a red vertical streak on the left side, putting the Maddox rod horizontally on the right eye
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Maddox rod on the right eye produces a red vertical streak seen by the right eye
  • White light is seen by the left eye
  • Crossed diplopia occurs when a streak appears on the left side and light on the right, indicating a temporal image seen by the nasal retina of the right eye → exodeviation (Option B ruled out)
  • Esophoria would produce uncrossed diplopia (streak on right, light on left) (Option C ruled out)
  • Hypertropia involves vertical deviation, not assessed in horizontal Maddox rod testing (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • The Maddox rod test helps detect latent strabismus (phorias)
  • Crossed images indicate exophoria
  • Uncrossed images indicate esophoria
